their Wi-Fi networks and online and so what is IOT though let's just talk about
that in a little bit of a basic sense first before I get into the really neat stuff at its core the Internet of Things
is simply two parts you've got a bunch of devices that are collecting data
they've got sensors on them they're sensing information about the world and you want to unlock that data you want to
do something interesting with that data and that means taking the data from the device and getting it up into the cloud
where you can analyze it and you can enrich that data and you can compare with other things and that's where you're gonna get your real business insight there's no sense in just having
a bunch of devices producing data if you can't do anything with it and so to start out we have our IOT core
services now this will handle things like the core messaging so we'll give
you an endpoint that all of your devices can securely communicate with with a certificate authentication and
encryption and once you've got your data sent up to the cloud we've got a message broker and a rules engine that will let
you dispatch that those dead pieces of data those events to different sources whether you just want to record that
data or whether you want to take action on that data fire off lambda functions this sort of thing and finally state
management right so in IOT you have devices that are not always online and so we make it easy to do things like
remember the last state that a particular device was in and its configuration and information about it and if you want to make a changes to
that state you know you can make changes with API calls without the dependent on that that device being online at the
time and when the device comes online we'll handle that state synchronization for you automatically and so I mentioned
simplistic before they've got this the roti Matic does anybody here have one of these yeah so is it cool it looks really

something called AWS Greengrass what Greengrass is is software that you can install on Greengrass compatible
devices at the edge and what I mean when I say edge is not in the cloud but somewhere close to or in some cases on
the devices themselves that are sensing and producing the data that you want to collect Greengrass has a lot of neat
features and brings a lot of the power from the cloud to your local devices firstly it can handle taking data from
other non Greengrass devices so they can communicate directly with the Greengrass hub or you know some software some
device running the Greengrass software that can that's compatible for running Greengrass it's encrypted automatically
so we also handle the secure encryption greengrass devices can act as a local certificate authority so you don't have
to worry about your devices communicating securely we manage all of that for you with the certificate management it'll also do that offline
state synchronization I talked about supporting device shadows if you know or I'm sorry think shadows which is the
term we use in AWS IOT to talk about a device and when it's online or offline and doing state synchronization and
finally the coolest feature I think is the ability to use the same execution model that you
could have in the cloud to respond to events locally at the edge when you might be offline so developers can build
applications and functions with AWS lambda and they can the Greengrass devices can run lambda so you can take
the same code that you've written already to work with AWS iot in the cloud and those lambdas can run locally
